thread.section_title: Business News, Economy, Finance & ASX Market News
thread.title: Macarthur Square in $240 million redevelopment

title: Macarthur Square in $240 million redevelopment
text:
An artist's impression of the expanded Macarthur Square shopping centre in Sydney's Campbelltown.
There is an abundance of shopping centre redevelopments across the country, even at airports, all designed to grab a bigger share of the tight household budget.
Macarthur Square shopping centre has been given the final nod for a $240 million facelift, to be undertaken by the joint owners, Australian Prime Property Fund Retail and GPT Wholesale Shopping Centre Fund.
The centre will also boast a new Aldi as demand mounts for more supermarkets, an expanded and refurbished Target, a new Harris Scarfe, and 550 new car spaces.
It will see the Campbelltown-based mall increase by 16,000 square metres to maintain its position as the largest shopping centre in south-west Sydney at 100,000 square metres.
As part of the upgrade, David Jones will continue with the rollout of its next-generation stores, that offer a range of new services to complement its click-and-collect business, which is now 10 per cent of orders, and new brands, as well as Wi-Fi, digital charging stations and an interactive "omni mirror".
Advertisement The centre will also boast a new Aldi as demand mounts for more supermarkets, an expanded and refurbished Target, a new Harris Scarfe, and 550 new car spaces.
Managing director of Lend Lease's investment management business, Kylie Rampa, said the centre will offer more fresh food and an expanded dining area.
Head of Lend Lease's retail business, Gary Horwitz, said the redevelopment will strengthen the position of Macarthur Square by "introducing an upgraded and revitalised shopping experience".
Construction is expected to take about two years, with the main extension complete before Christmas 2016. Lend Lease's Building business will design, project manage and construct the project.
The international terminal at the Sydney international airport is also undergoing significant change following the appointment of new duty free partner Heinemann.
The upgrade will see a transformation of the in and outbound areas, including a newly designed 1200 square metre duty free store in Pier C Arrivals, that will showcase an extensive range of fragrances, cosmetics, wine, liquor and confectionery and has been designed by Gebr, Heinemann's in-house design team, in collaboration with renowned Australian architectural firm Geyer. The project is set to be completed by mid-next year.
The retail sector redevelopment comes as advisory group BIS Shrapnel warns that shopping centre income will be soft as consumers remain committed to saving.
There is also concern about the performance of some anchor tenants in the wake of strong [overseas] competition, lower margin growth from the low Australian dollar, the continued growth of online retailing, and the quantum of new supply.
However, the ratio of saving has eased off, allowing more cash to be diverted to the shops.
In its latest report, BIS Shrapnel's senior project manager, Maria Lee, who authored the data, said the share of household income diverted to savings shot up after the global financial crisis and remained elevated for some years.
Ms Lee said BIS Shrapnel's latest Retail Property Market 2015 to 2025 report shows there was evidence that the amount being saved has started to fall, and is expected to fall further, providing an important boost to consumer spending on retail goods and services.
This is good news for retailers and shopping-centre owners.
"However, shopping-centre income growth will remain constrained due to a number of other headwinds that are expected to persist into the medium term," Ms Lee said.
"The falling savings ratio is key. Despite weak growth in incomes, consumers are seemingly willing to loosen the purse strings slightly, reducing their levels of precautionary savings. That's likely a result of record low interest rates and low inflation".
